page.title: 02Valley of the Sydling Water
page.content: This valley has provided home and shelter for people since ancient times. Long before the Romans came to Dorset in 54AD there was a Celtic village on our hillside. In the 2nd half of the 6th century the West Saxons arrived and probably lived in uneasy harmony with the Romano British. It was the saxons who cleared the hills of trees and in order to use their heavy eight-ox ploughs, made and cultivated the strips or lynchets along the hillsides which can still be seen today. There are field systems on the Crofts Down, Middle Hill, & between Loscombe Hill & Folly Hill, Tumulus on Elston Hill, Cross Hill, North Field Hill, Cowdown Hill,& Larkham Bottom; earth works on Cross Hill, at the bottom of Hog Hill. Spring rises at Up Sydling & flows right through the village.
